Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Programmed Intermittent Epidural Bolus Intervals for Labor Analgesia

Trial_Design.evidence: double-blinded, randomised controlled trial included 100 nulliparous women

Participants.evidence: 100 nulliparous women with singleton pregnancies at ≥37 weeks gestation

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to one of five PIEB intervals (35, 40, 45, 50, or 55 minutes)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the optimal interval for programmed intermittent epidural bolus (PIEB) analgesia

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was effective analgesia, defined as no requirement for patient-controlled epidural analgesia (PCEA) during the first stage of labor.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients and outcome assessors.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The estimated PIEB intervals for 50% (EI50) and 90% (EI90) effectiveness were 52.5 (95% CI, 48.4–62.6) and 37.0 (95% CI, 28.4–40.9) minutes, respectively.

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported
